metadata.titleEn: Mitochondrial genome sequencing data of Tibetan population in Lhasa
metadata.description: The whole mitochondrial genomes of 68 Tibetan samples were sequenced by high-throughput second-generation sequencing. The average depth of sequencing was 1000 ×, ensuring that the mitochondrial genome of each sample was completely covered (100%). Based on the phylogenetic analysis, we control the quality of these data to ensure that there is no sample pollution and other quality problems. According to the phylogenetic tree, each individual was allocated into haplogroups. The results showed that in Lhasa Tibetan population, M9a1c1b1a was the highest (19.12%), followed by G2 (13.23%), M13a (11.76%), C4a (7.35%), D4 (7.35%), A11a1a (5.88%), M9a1b (5.88%), and F1c, F1g, B4, F1d, M62b, F1a, F1b, G1, M11, M8a, U7a, Z3a. These haplogroups have different originations, including Paleolithic components (M13a, M62b, M9a1b, etc.), northern China millet farmers’ components (M9a1c1b1a and A11a1a), components distributed mainly in southern East Asia (F1a, etc.), northern East Asian haplogroups (C4a, D4, etc.). It is worth noting that the maternal component of Lhasa Tibetans is mainly composed of millet agricultural population in northern China, indicating the important impact of genetic input of millet agricultural population in northern China on the genetic structure of the population in this area. Taken together, the maternal genetic structure of Lhasa Tibetan population exhibits time stratification, which may represent the genetic imprint of different population entering the region in different periods.
metadata.instructions: Fas format, you can use text editor (such as EDITPLUS) and mega to open view and analysis.

authorList.unitEn: Kunming Institute of Zoology, Chinese Academy of Sciences

literatureList.titleEn: Neolithic millet farmers contributed to the permanent settlement of the Tibetan Plateau by adopting barley agriculture
literatureList.referenceEn: Li, Y.C., Tian, J.Y., Liu, F.W., Yang, B.Y., Gu, K.S.Y., Rahman, Z.U., Yang, L.Q., Chen, F.H., Dong, G.H., Kong, Q.P. (2019). Neolithic millet farmers contributed to the permanent settlement of the Tibetan Plateau by adopting barley agriculture, National Science Review, Volume 6, Issue 5, September 2019, Pages 1005–1013, https://doi.org/10.1093/nsr/nwz080

background: With an extreme and harsh environment that is generally considered inhospitable to humans, the Tibetan Plateau (TP) has been inhabited since the late upper Pleistocene. In contrast to the earliest occupation by hunter-gatherers during the Late Paleolithic era, whose contribution to the current Tibetan gene pool was rather limited, migration onto the plateau appears to have occurred during the Neolithic period. Archaeological evidence further suggests that permanent human occupation began ∼3.6 kilo-years ago (ka), and was most likely facilitated by the introduction and utilization of cold-tolerant barley agriculture and sheep, which were first domesticated in west Asia around 10 ka. As revealed by archaeological evidence, modern humans settled extensively in the northeastern TP (below 2500 m above sea level (masl)) with millet cultivation around ∼5.2 ka, and further expanded to high-altitude plateau areas (above 2500 masl) ∼3.6 ka with barley and sheep from west Asia. According to previous genetic studies, most Tibetan genetic components can be traced back to Neolithic immigrations from northern China, raising the possibility that it was millet farmers who brought barley agriculture to the TP around 3.6 ka. Given the limited molecular resolution, and a lack of both genetic and archaeological evidence in previous studies, it remains unclear whether these lineages are associated with millet farmers or with the immigration of foragers during the early Holocene (∼11.7–8.3 ka).
research objective: In this study, by exploring mitogenomes in Tibetans and surrounding populations (especially those with suggested Neolithic millet farmer ancestry), as well as radiocarbon dating of cereal remains from archaeological sites on the TP and northern China, we aimed to address whether millet farmers contributed to the Tibetan gene pool at the time of barley dispersal to the TP (∼3.6 ka), thus providing deeper insight into the origin of Tibetans.
methods: Blood samples from 671 Tibetans from 11 Tibetan populations were collected, covering all seven districts of Tibet. Blood samples from an additional 11 Chinese individuals belonging to haplogroups of interest were also collected for mitogenome sequencing. Complete mtDNA genomes of the samples were enriched by capture-based strategies using a MyGenostics Human Mitochondria Capture Kit (MyGenostics Inc., Beijing, China). Sequencing was carried out using an Illumina HiSeq X Ten platform at MyGenostics. Quality control was performed according to previous research. The sequencing outputs were edited and aligned by Lasergene (DNAStar Inc., Madison, Wisconsin, USA) and compared with the revised Cambridge Reference Sequence. Phylogenetic trees of lineages of interest were reconstructed manually based on the complete sequences and confirmed by mtphyl software. Bayesian skyline plots (BSP) for effective population size (Nef) through time were reconstructed based on 13 protein coding regions using BEAST v1.7.5. In detail, 20 samples were picked randomly from each of the 11 Tibetan populations and pooled as one data set to perform BSP analysis.
dataset: Blood samples from 671 Tibetans from 11 Tibetan populations were collected, covering all seven districts of Tibet. Blood samples from an additional 11 Chinese individuals belonging to haplogroups of interest were also collected for mitogenome sequencing.
findings: M9a1a1c1b1a and A11a1a were more frequent in Tibetans ∼3.6 ka. Both M9a1a1c1b1a and A11a1a are distributed ubiquitously in contemporary Tibetans, with total frequencies ranging from 12.0% (Baqing County, Naqu) to 37.5% (Ngari) across all regional Tibetan populations studied. This suggests that the millet farmer lineages contributed to and existed in the proto-gene pool of Tibetans before their expansion to different regions on the TP. Indeed, much closer genetic affinity was observed among all regional Tibetan populations, with haplogroup M9a1a1c1b1a contributing most to this clustering pattern, implying that millet farmer components played an important role in shaping the genetic landscape of Tibetans.

Verification.Question: Are high-throughput second-generation sequencing methods used for mitochondrial genome sequencing in Tibetan populations?
Is quality control performed to ensure there is no sample contamination in the sequencing data?

Disjunctive.Question: Is the main sequencing platform used for mitochondrial genome data collection in Tibetans the Illumina HiSeq, MyGenostics, or another platform?
Are blood samples from Tibetan populations collected from a single district, all districts of Tibet, or selectively from regions with specific haplogroups?

Concept Completion.Question: Who is involved in the data collection of Tibetan mitochondrial genomes?
What data collection method is used for sequencing the mitochondrial genomes of the Tibetan population?
Where is the source location for the blood samples used in the mitochondrial genome study?

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset that illustrates the genetic contribution of ancient populations to modern human groups?
Example.Answer: A dataset that illustrates the genetic contribution of ancient populations to modern human groups includes blood samples from 671 Tibetans across 11 populations, covering all seven districts of Tibet, used to explore the distribution of haplogroups such as M9a1a1c1b1a and A11a1a, which are linked to Neolithic millet farmers.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a research approach that integrates phylogenetic analysis with mitochondrial DNA sequencing?
Example.Answer: A research approach that integrates phylogenetic analysis with mitochondrial DNA sequencing involves reconstructing phylogenetic trees manually based on complete mitogenome sequences and confirming them using mtphyl software, as demonstrated in the analysis of Tibetan and surrounding populations' mitogenomes.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific sequencing technologies utilized for obtaining mitochondrial genome data from human populations?
What characteristics of haplogroups are analyzed to determine their prevalence and distribution among Tibetan populations?
Feature Specification.Answer: phylogenetic tree construction, quality-controlled sequencing data, M9a1a1c1b1a haplogroup prevalence

Quantification.Question: How many Tibetan samples were collected for mitogenome sequencing?
What is the sequencing depth used for the mitochondrial genome data collection?
How many haplogroups of interest were involved in the additional sample collection from Chinese individuals?

Definition.Question: What does 'high-throughput sequencing' mean in the context of collecting genomic data from specific populations?
Definition.Answer: High-throughput sequencing in this context refers to using advanced sequencing technology to perform complete mitochondrial genome sequencing on multiple samples from a specific population, ensuring high coverage and depth to capture comprehensive genetic information.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'phylogenetic tree' when analyzing genetic data from population studies?
Definition.Answer: A phylogenetic tree in genetic studies is a diagram that represents the evolutionary relationships among various haplogroups or genetic lineages, based on complete mitochondrial sequences, which helps in classifying individuals into specific haplogroups and understanding their genetic ancestry and diversity.

Comparison.Question: How does the data collection method of mitogenome sequencing using a capture-based strategy compare to high-throughput second-generation sequencing in terms of efficiency and coverage?
Comparison.Answer: The mitogenome sequencing using a capture-based strategy involved enriching complete mtDNA genomes and sequencing on an Illumina HiSeq X Ten platform, while high-throughput second-generation sequencing involved sequencing with an average depth of 1000× to ensure 100% coverage of the mitochondrial genome. Both methods ensure high coverage, but the capture-based strategy focuses on specific regions, potentially improving efficiency for targeted haplogroups.

Interpretation.Question: How could the integration of archaeological evidence with genetic data enhance the interpretation of human migration patterns on the Tibetan Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating archaeological evidence with genetic data can provide a more comprehensive understanding of human migration patterns by linking genetic findings with cultural and technological developments, such as the introduction of agriculture. This approach can clarify the timing and nature of migrations, revealing whether genetic lineages are associated with specific cultural practices, like millet farming, that facilitated human settlement in harsh environments.

Interpretation.Question: What methodological considerations are important for designing a dataset that aims to explore the genetic contributions of Neolithic farmers to modern Tibetan populations?
Interpretation.Answer: Designing a dataset to explore Neolithic farmer contributions involves selecting representative samples from various Tibetan populations, ensuring complete mitochondrial genome sequencing, and employing phylogenetic analysis. It also requires considering historical agricultural practices and their genetic impacts, using techniques like Bayesian skyline plots to infer population size changes over time and identify ancient genetic influences.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is quality control crucial in the data collection process of mitochondrial genome sequencing, especially when studying ancient lineages?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Quality control is essential to ensure the absence of sample contamination and other quality issues, which is critical when studying ancient lineages. This is because accurate lineage classification and phylogenetic analysis depend on the integrity and purity of the genetic data collected, which can be compromised by contamination or sequencing errors.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the interest in studying the maternal lineage contributions from millet farmers to the Tibetan gene pool using mitochondrial genome data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The interest arises from the hypothesis that millet farmers significantly contributed to the Tibetan gene pool during the Neolithic period, particularly with the dispersal of barley agriculture. By studying mitochondrial genome data, researchers aim to trace these ancestral lineages and understand their impact on the genetic landscape of contemporary Tibetan populations.

Causal Consequence.Question: What is the impact on data quality if high-throughput second-generation sequencing methods are used for mitochondrial genome sequencing in Tibetan populations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using high-throughput second-generation sequencing methods for mitochondrial genome sequencing in Tibetan populations ensures a high average sequencing depth of 1000×, which guarantees complete genome coverage and allows for effective quality control to prevent sample contamination. This method supports accurate haplogroup classification and contributes to a robust understanding of the genetic structure and history of the population.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the use of a MyGenostics Human Mitochondria Capture Kit affect the completeness and accuracy of mitochondrial DNA sequencing?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of a MyGenostics Human Mitochondria Capture Kit in mitochondrial DNA sequencing allows for the enrichment of complete mtDNA genomes, which enhances the accuracy and completeness of the sequencing process. This approach facilitates the detailed reconstruction of phylogenetic trees and the identification of haplogroups, aiding in the exploration of genetic ancestry and population history.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of sequencing mitochondrial genomes across different Tibetan populations?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to explore mitogenomes in Tibetans and surrounding populations, especially those with suggested Neolithic millet farmer ancestry, to address whether millet farmers contributed to the Tibetan gene pool at the time of barley dispersal to the Tibetan Plateau, providing deeper insight into the origin of Tibetans.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to reconstruct phylogenetic trees of lineages using complete mitochondrial sequences?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Reconstructing phylogenetic trees using complete mitochondrial sequences is important to confirm the lineage relationships and to understand the genetic structure and historical migrations that contributed to the current genetic landscape of the Tibetan populations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What processes and technologies are utilized to ensure the comprehensive quality control and contamination prevention in mitochondrial genome sequencing for Tibetan populations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Quality control is ensured through systematic checks to prevent sample contamination, and phylogenetic analysis is used to check for haplotype group classification, ensuring no quality issues. Sequencing is performed with an average depth of 1000× to guarantee complete coverage of the mitochondrial genome for each sample.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can phylogenetic trees be manually constructed and confirmed for lineages of interest in mitochondrial DNA studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Phylogenetic trees of lineages of interest are manually reconstructed based on complete sequences and confirmed using mtphyl software to ensure accuracy in lineage classification and analysis.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the detailed steps involved in using Bayesian skyline plots for analyzing effective population size changes over time in mitochondrial DNA studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Bayesian skyline plots are constructed using BEAST v1.7.5 based on 13 protein-coding regions. Samples from different populations are pooled as one data set for the analysis, providing insights into effective population size changes through time.

Enablement.Question: What sequencing technologies have enabled the comprehensive coverage of mitochondrial genomes in Tibetan populations?
Enablement.Answer: High-throughput second-generation sequencing methods, specifically using an Illumina HiSeq platform, have enabled comprehensive coverage of mitochondrial genomes with a high average sequencing depth of 1000x, ensuring full coverage of each sample.

Enablement.Question: How do capture-based strategies aid in the enrichment of complete mitochondrial DNA genomes from blood samples?
Enablement.Answer: Capture-based strategies, such as those using the MyGenostics Human Mitochondria Capture Kit, concentrate on enriching complete mitochondrial DNA genomes from blood samples, allowing for detailed sequencing and subsequent phylogenetic analysis.

Enablement.Question: What data quality control measures ensure the reliability of mitochondrial genome data collected from Tibetan populations?
Enablement.Answer: Quality control measures, which include editing and aligning sequencing outputs with the revised Cambridge Reference Sequence and reconstructing phylogenetic trees, are implemented to prevent sample contamination and ensure data reliability.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in ensuring complete mitochondrial genome coverage in sequencing data from Tibetan populations?
Expectation.Answer: The sequencing method used involves high-throughput techniques with an average depth of 1000× to ensure complete coverage. However, challenges such as sample contamination, insufficient depth in some regions, or technical limitations in sequencing platforms could affect complete genome coverage.

Expectation.Question: What might be some reasons for differences in haplogroup frequencies across different Tibetan populations, and how could data collection methods account for this?
Expectation.Answer: Haplogroup frequency differences could arise from historical migration patterns, genetic drift, or specific selection pressures. Data collection methods such as gathering samples from diverse geographic locations and ensuring representative sampling from all sub-populations are crucial in capturing these variations accurately.

Expectation.Question: Why is it important to perform quality control and phylogenetic analysis when collecting mitochondrial genome data, and what challenges might arise if these steps are omitted?
Expectation.Answer: Quality control and phylogenetic analysis are vital to ensure the accuracy and reliability of genetic data, preventing errors such as contamination or misalignment. Without these steps, there could be incorrect haplogroup classification and misinterpretation of genetic relationships among populations.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using high-throughput sequencing methods for achieving complete mitochondrial genome coverage in genetic studies of specific populations?
Judgmental.Answer: High-throughput sequencing methods are highly effective in achieving complete mitochondrial genome coverage, as demonstrated by their use in sequencing 68 Tibetan samples with an average depth of 1000×, ensuring 100% coverage and allowing for detailed haplogroup classification.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential challenges and solutions in maintaining sample quality and avoiding contamination during the data collection process in genetic studies involving diverse populations?
Judgmental.Answer: Maintaining sample quality and avoiding contamination are critical challenges. Solutions include rigorous quality control based on phylogenetic analysis, as described in the data collection process for Tibetan populations, ensuring no sample contamination and accurate haplogroup classification.

Judgmental.Question: How might the use of phylogenetic tree reconstruction and Bayesian skyline plots enhance the understanding of population dynamics and genetic ancestry in genetic studies?
Judgmental.Answer: Phylogenetic tree reconstruction and Bayesian skyline plots provide deeper insights into population dynamics and genetic ancestry by allowing researchers to trace lineage expansion and evaluate effective population sizes over time, as utilized in analyzing Tibetan populations to understand genetic contributions from ancient populations.

Assertion.Question: I'm not sure why geographic coverage of sample collection is important in genetic studies of human populations.
Assertion.Answer: Geographic coverage is important because it ensures a representative sampling of genetic diversity across different populations and regions. In genetic studies of human populations, it helps identify lineage frequencies and genetic structure, as seen in the collection from all seven districts of Tibet.

Assertion.Question: I can't figure out why capturing high sequencing depth is necessary for analyzing mitochondrial genomes.
Assertion.Answer: High sequencing depth, such as the average 1000× depth mentioned, ensures complete coverage and accuracy in mitochondrial genome sequencing. It is crucial for quality control, preventing sample contamination, and making precise haplogroup classifications.
